name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PM-KISAN)
description: Direct income support scheme for farmers that provides ₹6,000 per year to land‑holding farmer families in three instalments of ₹2,000 each, via Direct Benefit Transfer.
target_group: Landholding farmers across India

other: Must be a landholding farmer family
Subject to certain exclusions for higher income groups, government employees, etc.

benefits: Financial assistance of ₹6,000 per year
Disbursed in three equal installments of ₹2,000 every four months
Direct transfer to beneficiary bank accounts

steps: Register through local Common Service Centers (CSCs)
Submit required documents to verify land ownership
Bank account must be linked with Aadhaar
how_to_apply.deadline: None - Ongoing scheme with periodic enrollment windows

faq.q: Is eKYC mandatory for PM-KISAN?
faq.a: Yes, beneficiaries must complete eKYC to continue receiving payments.

faq.q: How will I know if my payment is processed?
faq.a: You can check your status on the PM-KISAN portal using your registration number.

faq.q: Who is excluded from PM-KISAN benefits?
faq.a: Institutional landholders, higher income tax payers, professionals, and government employees are generally excluded.

name: Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY)
description: A comprehensive crop insurance scheme that provides financial support to farmers in case of crop damage or loss due to unforeseen events.
target_group: All farmers including sharecroppers and tenant farmers

other: Farmers growing notified crops in notified areas
Both loanee and non-loanee farmers can participate

benefits: Insurance coverage for the entire crop cycle
Protection against yield losses due to natural calamities, pests, and diseases
Low premium rates subsidized by government
Use of technology for quick claim settlement

how_to_apply.mode: Through banks, insurance companies, or CSCs
steps: Approach local bank branch, insurance company, or CSC
Fill the proposal form for the notified crop

faq.q: What are the premium rates under PMFBY?
faq.a: 2% for Kharif crops, 1.5% for Rabi crops, and 5% for commercial/horticultural crops.

faq.q: How are claims settled?
faq.a: Claims are settled based on yield data from Crop Cutting Experiments (CCEs) or weather parameters as applicable.

faq.q: Is the scheme mandatory for farmers with crop loans?
faq.a: The scheme was made voluntary for all farmers from Kharif 2020 season.

name: Soil Health Card Scheme
description: Initiative to issue soil health cards to farmers containing crop-wise recommendations for nutrients and fertilizers to help farmers improve productivity through judicious use of inputs.
target_group: All farmers across India

other: All farmers with agricultural land are eligible

benefits: Soil health cards issued every 3 years
Detailed analysis of soil nutrient status
Crop-specific fertilizer recommendations
Promotes balanced use of fertilizers
Helps improve soil health and crop productivity

steps: Receive soil health card with recommendations

faq.q: How often are soil health cards issued?
faq.a: Soil Health Cards are issued once every three years.

faq.q: What information does the soil health card contain?
faq.a: It contains the status of soil with respect to 12 parameters including N,P,K (Macro-nutrients); S (Secondary nutrient); Zn, Fe, Cu, Mn, Bo (Micro-nutrients); and pH, EC, OC (Physical parameters).

faq.q: Is there any fee for soil testing?
faq.a: Soil testing under the scheme is generally free for farmers.

name: Pradhan Mantri Krishi Sinchai Yojana (PMKSY)
description: A centrally sponsored scheme aimed at expanding cultivated area with assured irrigation, reducing wastage of water, and improving water use efficiency.
target_group: Farmers requiring irrigation support

other: Priority to small and marginal farmers

benefits: Expanded irrigation coverage ('Har Khet Ko Pani')
Improved water-use efficiency ('More Crop Per Drop')
Micro-irrigation systems subsidized
Creation of new water sources and restoration of existing water bodies
Enhanced recharge of aquifers

steps: Contact local agriculture or irrigation department office
Submit application for specific component of PMKSY

faq.q: What are the main components of PMKSY?
faq.a: The main components are Accelerated Irrigation Benefit Programme (AIBP), Har Khet Ko Pani, Per Drop More Crop, and Watershed Development.

faq.q: What type of irrigation methods are promoted under PMKSY?
faq.a: PMKSY promotes micro-irrigation techniques like drip and sprinkler irrigation.

faq.q: Is there any subsidy available under the scheme?
faq.a: Yes, subsidies are available for micro-irrigation systems and other components, with rates varying by state.

name: e-National Agriculture Market (e-NAM)
description: Pan-India electronic trading platform that creates a unified national market for agricultural commodities by networking existing APMC mandis.
target_group: Farmers, traders, and buyers of agricultural produce

other: Farmers, FPOs, traders registered with participating APMC mandis

benefits: Transparent price discovery mechanism
Access to nationwide market for better prices
Reduced transaction costs
Online payments
Quality assaying of produce

steps: Visit the nearest e-NAM registered APMC mandi
Register on the e-NAM portal or through mobile app

faq.q: Who manages the e-NAM platform?
faq.a: e-NAM is managed by the Small Farmers Agribusiness Consortium (SFAC) under Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare.

faq.q: Do I need to physically go to the mandi after registering on e-NAM?
faq.a: Initially yes, but e-NAM is progressively introducing features for remote trading.

faq.q: Is quality assaying mandatory for trading on e-NAM?
faq.a: Quality assaying is encouraged for better price discovery but may not be mandatory for all commodities.

name: Agriculture Infrastructure Fund (AIF)
description: A financing facility for the creation of post-harvest management infrastructure and community farming assets through interest subvention and credit guarantee support.
target_group: Farmers, FPOs, Agri-entrepreneurs, Start-ups, and Central/State agencies

other: Farmers, FPOs, PACS, Marketing Cooperative Societies, SHGs
Agri-entrepreneurs, Start-ups, Agribusiness companies
Central/State agency or local body sponsored Public-Private Partnership Projects

benefits: Interest subvention of 3% per annum for loans up to Rs. 2 crore
Credit guarantee coverage for loans up to Rs. 2 crore
Long repayment period of up to 7 years
Moratorium period of up to 2 years
Support for various post-harvest infrastructure projects

steps: Interest subvention and credit guarantee provided

required_documents: Registration documents of organization (for FPOs, startups, etc.)

faq.q: What type of projects can be funded under AIF?
faq.a: Post-harvest management projects like cold storage, pack houses, sorting & grading units, warehouses, e-marketing platforms, etc.

faq.q: What is the loan amount available under AIF?
faq.a: Loans from Rs. 10 lakh to Rs. 2 crore are eligible for interest subvention and credit guarantee coverage.

faq.q: How long will the scheme be operational?
faq.a: The scheme will be operational from 2020-21 to 2032-33.

name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Urja Suraksha evam Utthaan Mahabhiyan (PM-KUSUM)
description: Launched in March 2019, the scheme offers up to 60% subsidy (30% Central + 30% State) on solar irrigation pumps to farmers and enables sale of surplus power back to the grid.
target_group: Farmers requiring energy solutions for agriculture

other: Individual farmers for standalone solar pumps
Grid-connected pump owners for solarization
Farmers, FPOs, Panchayats for setting up solar power plants

benefits: Up to 60% subsidy on solar pumps
Income generation through sale of surplus power to grid
Reduced dependency on diesel for irrigation
Lower electricity bills for grid-connected pumps
Sustainable irrigation solutions

steps: Contact state nodal agency for renewable energy/agriculture department
Submit application form with required documents
Site assessment conducted by implementing agency
Approval and installation by empanelled vendors

faq.q: What are the components of PM-KUSUM scheme?
faq.a: Component A: Setting up of 10,000 MW of Decentralized Ground/Stilt Mounted Grid Connected Solar Power Plants, Component B: Installation of 20 lakh standalone Solar Powered Agriculture Pumps, and Component C: Solarization of 15 lakh existing Grid-connected Agriculture Pumps.

faq.q: What is the subsidy pattern under PM-KUSUM?
faq.a: Up to 60% subsidy (30% central + 30% state) for standalone solar pumps. Subsidy patterns may vary by component and state.

faq.q: Can I get a pump of any capacity under this scheme?
faq.a: The scheme generally covers pumps up to 7.5 HP capacity, with specific criteria set by states.

name: Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana (PMMSY)
description: A flagship scheme for sustainable and responsible development of the fisheries sector in India, with investments in infrastructure, activities, and welfare measures.
target_group: Fishers, fish farmers, fish workers, and entrepreneurs in the fisheries sector

other: Fishers, fish farmers, fish workers
Fisheries cooperatives/federations
Self Help Groups (SHGs) in fisheries sector
Entrepreneurs, private companies in fisheries sector
State governments and entities

benefits: Infrastructure development for fisheries
Support for fish production and productivity
Higher subsidies for SC/ST/women beneficiaries
Insurance coverage for fishers
Marketing support and value addition facilities

faq.q: What is the duration of the PMMSY scheme?
faq.a: PMMSY is implemented for a period of 5 years from FY 2020-21 to FY 2024-25.

faq.q: What is the subsidy pattern under PMMSY?
faq.a: Subsidy up to 40% for general category and up to 60% for SC/ST/women beneficiaries in most components.

faq.q: Does PMMSY cover both marine and inland fisheries?
faq.a: Yes, PMMSY covers both marine and inland fisheries, as well as aquaculture.

name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan SAMPADA Yojana
description: A comprehensive package to create modern infrastructure with efficient supply chain management from farm gate to retail outlet.
target_group: Food processors, farmer producer organizations, cooperatives, and entrepreneurs

other: Individuals, partnerships, companies in food processing
FPOs, NGOs, cooperatives, SHGs
Central/State PSUs
Joint ventures

benefits: Financial assistance for setting up food processing units
Creation of modern infrastructure for food processing
Reduction in wastage of agricultural produce
Enhanced shelf life of food products
Better returns to farmers

steps: Submit detailed project report with required documents
Approval and fund disbursement in installments

faq.q: What are the components under PM Kisan SAMPADA Yojana?
faq.a: The major components include Mega Food Parks, Integrated Cold Chain, Creation/Expansion of Food Processing Units, Infrastructure for Agro-Processing Clusters, Food Safety & Quality Assurance Infrastructure, and Operation Greens.

faq.q: What is the grant-in-aid pattern under the scheme?
faq.a: It varies by component, generally ranging from 35% to 75% of the eligible project cost, with maximum caps defined for each component.

faq.q: Can individuals apply for all components of the scheme?
faq.a: Some components like Mega Food Parks are primarily for companies/SPVs, while others like food processing units can be accessed by individuals.

name: National Beekeeping and Honey Mission (NBHM)
description: A scheme to promote holistic growth of the beekeeping industry for income and employment generation, enhance crop productivity, and ensure food security.
target_group: Beekeepers, farmers interested in beekeeping, entrepreneurs in honey sector

other: Individual beekeepers
Farmers interested in beekeeping
Self Help Groups (SHGs)
FPOs focused on beekeeping
Cooperatives and federations in beekeeping sector

benefits: Financial assistance for setting up beekeeping units
Support for honey processing infrastructure
Training and capacity building in scientific beekeeping
Quality control testing facilities
Marketing support for honey and other bee products

how_to_apply.mode: Through National Bee Board or state horticulture missions
steps: Contact state horticulture department or National Bee Board
Submit application form with project details

faq.q: What type of support is provided under NBHM?
faq.a: Support includes assistance for beehives and colonies, equipment, processing infrastructure, training, quality testing labs, and research & development.

faq.q: Is there training provided for new beekeepers?
faq.a: Yes, the scheme includes components for training and capacity building in scientific beekeeping methods.

faq.q: Can I get support for marketing my honey products?
faq.a: Yes, the scheme includes provisions for supporting marketing infrastructure and brand promotion for honey and other bee products.

name: National Mission on Edible Oils – Oil Palm (NMEO-OP)
description: A centrally sponsored scheme to increase the production of palm oil in India through area expansion, support to farmers, and creation of processing infrastructure.
target_group: Farmers in identified areas suitable for oil palm cultivation

eligibility.residency: Indian farmer in identified potential areas
other: Farmers with land suitable for oil palm cultivation
Farmers in identified potential districts/states
FPOs and cooperatives in oil palm sector
Processing companies with farmer linkages

benefits: Financial assistance for planting material
Maintenance cost support during gestation period
Support for drip irrigation systems
Assistance for intercropping during gestation period
Support for processing units and seed gardens

steps: Registration and allocation of planting material

required_documents: Soil and water testing reports (if required)

faq.q: What is the gestation period for oil palm cultivation?
faq.a: Oil palm has a gestation period of 3-4 years before commercial production begins.

faq.q: Is there any price assurance for oil palm farmers?
faq.a: Yes, the scheme includes a viability price mechanism to protect farmers from fluctuations in international CPO prices.

faq.q: In which states is oil palm cultivation being promoted?
faq.a: The scheme focuses on North-Eastern states and Andaman & Nicobar Islands primarily, along with other potential states identified based on suitability assessment.

name: Sub-Mission on Agricultural Mechanization (SMAM)
description: A scheme to increase the reach of farm mechanization to small and marginal farmers and to regions where availability of farm power is low.
target_group: Individual farmers, farmer groups, custom hiring centers

other: All categories of farmers eligible with focus on small and marginal farmers
SHGs, cooperatives, FPOs for establishing custom hiring centers
Entrepreneurs for farm machinery banks

benefits: Subsidy on purchase of agricultural machinery and equipment
Support for establishing custom hiring centers
Training on operation and maintenance of machinery
Demonstrations of new technology machines
Creating hubs for hi-tech and high-value agricultural equipment

faq.q: What is the subsidy pattern under SMAM?
faq.a: Subsidy varies from 40-50% for individual beneficiaries depending on the category and up to 80% for custom hiring centers, with different rates for different categories of equipment and northeastern states.

faq.q: Can I get subsidy for any type of agricultural machinery?
faq.a: Subsidy is available only for approved list of machines with specified technical specifications.

faq.q: Is training provided on how to use the machinery?
faq.a: Yes, the scheme includes components for training and capacity building on operation and maintenance of farm machinery.

name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maan Dhan Yojana (PM-KMY)
description: A voluntary and contributory pension scheme for small and marginal farmers aged 18–40 with up to 2 ha of cultivable land (and not covered under other social security/pension schemes), contributing monthly sums that the government matches. On maturity at age 60, they receive ₹3,000/month pension.
target_group: Small and marginal farmers across India

other: Small and marginal farmers aged between 18 and 40 years
Cultivable land up to 2 hectares as per land records
Should not be covered under any other statutory social security scheme
Not income tax payer

benefits: Monthly pension of ₹3,000 after attaining the age of 60 years
Family pension to spouse in case of death of the beneficiary
Return of accumulated amount with interest to nominee in case of death during subscription period
Government contribution equal to beneficiary contribution

steps: Visit nearest CSC or PM-KMY enrollment center
Fill the enrollment form with required details
Pay the monthly contribution as per age
Receive pension card and start contributing

required_documents: Land Records (to verify small/marginal farmer status)

faq.q: What is the contribution amount under PM-KMY?
faq.a: The monthly contribution ranges from ₹55 to ₹200 depending on the entry age of the farmer.

faq.q: What happens if I stop paying the contribution?
faq.a: The account will become dormant after non-payment for a specified period, but can be revived by paying the outstanding dues with interest.

faq.q: Can I exit from the scheme before 60 years of age?
faq.a: Yes, voluntary exit is permitted. However, only the beneficiary's contributions with accumulated interest will be returned, not the government's contribution.

name: Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana (RKVY-RAFTAAR)
description: Launched in August 2007 as part of the 11th Five Year Plan and rebranded in 2017 as RKVY-RAFTAAR, this scheme incentivizes states to boost public investment in agriculture and allied sectors, with a focus on innovation, agritech startups, and value-chain interventions.
target_group: State governments, farmers, agritech startups

other: State governments must prepare district-level agricultural plans
For startups: Must be registered entities with viable agricultural innovations

benefits: Financial support for agricultural infrastructure development
Funding for innovation and agritech startups
Support for value-chain interventions
Customized agricultural planning at district level

steps: Plans are submitted to State-level sanctioning committees
For startups: Apply through designated state nodal agencies

required_documents: For startups: Registration documents, business plan, innovation details

faq.q: How does RKVY-RAFTAAR support agritech startups?
faq.a: The scheme provides funding and mentorship to agritech startups with innovative solutions for agricultural challenges.

faq.q: What is the difference between RKVY and RKVY-RAFTAAR?
faq.a: RKVY-RAFTAAR is the 2017 rebranded version that adds focus on innovation, startups, and value-chain interventions to the original RKVY scheme launched in 2007.

faq.q: Who implements RKVY-RAFTAAR?
faq.a: It is implemented by the Department of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare through State-level sanctioning committees.

name: Paramparagat Krishi Vikas Yojana (PKVY)
description: Launched in 2015-16 under the National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture, this scheme promotes cluster-based organic farming across India with a target to bring 6 lakh hectares under certified organic farming by 2025-26.
target_group: Farmers interested in organic farming

other: Farmers must be willing to form clusters of at least 50 farmers
Minimum area of 50 hectares per cluster
Commitment to organic farming practices

benefits: Financial assistance of ₹31,500 per hectare over three years
Support for on-farm/off-farm organic inputs (₹15,000/ha)
Marketing support (₹4,500/ha)
Organic certification support (₹3,000/ha)
Training on organic practices (₹9,000/ha)

steps: Form a farming cluster of at least 50 farmers
Submit cluster proposal through state agriculture department
how_to_apply.deadline: Ongoing scheme with seasonal application windows

faq.q: What is the target area under PKVY?
faq.a: The scheme aims to bring 6 lakh hectares under certified organic farming by 2025-26.

faq.q: What type of certification is provided under PKVY?
faq.a: The scheme supports PGS (Participatory Guarantee System) certification for organic farming.

faq.q: Can individual farmers apply for PKVY?
faq.a: No, farmers need to form clusters of at least 50 farmers covering minimum 50 hectares to avail benefits under this scheme.

name: Pradhan Mantri Annadata Aay Sanrakshan Abhiyan (PM-AASHA)
description: Announced in September 2018 as an umbrella scheme to ensure farmers receive the notified Minimum Support Price (MSP) for their produce through multiple mechanisms.
target_group: Farmers growing notified crops eligible for MSP

other: Must grow crops covered under MSP
Should follow prescribed quality standards for the produce

benefits: Guaranteed MSP for notified crops
Price Support Scheme (PSS) for direct procurement at MSP
Price Deficiency Payment Scheme (PDPS) for compensation when market prices fall below MSP
Private Procurement & Stockist Scheme (PPSS) for procurement by private players with a financial incentive

steps: Register at local procurement centers when operational
For PDPS: Register on designated portal during announced windows
how_to_apply.deadline: Seasonal, based on crop harvesting periods

faq.q: What are the components of PM-AASHA?
faq.a: PM-AASHA has three components: Price Support Scheme (PSS), Price Deficiency Payment Scheme (PDPS), and Private Procurement & Stockist Scheme (PPSS).

faq.q: Which crops are covered under PM-AASHA?
faq.a: The scheme covers all notified crops for which MSP is announced by the government.

faq.q: Who implements PM-AASHA?
faq.a: It is implemented jointly by the Department of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare and the Department of Consumer Affairs.

name: National Food Security & Nutrition Mission (NFSNM)
description: Launched as National Food Security Mission (NFSM) in October 2007 and renamed as NFSNM in 2024-25, this scheme aims to increase production of key food crops including rice, wheat, pulses, coarse cereals, and nutri-cereals through area expansion and productivity enhancement.
target_group: Farmers cultivating food crops

other: Farmers in identified districts growing targeted crops
Priority to small and marginal farmers

benefits: Subsidized quality seeds and planting materials
Farm mechanization support
Soil health management assistance
Integrated pest management training
Cropping system based interventions
Marketing support for nutri-cereals

steps: Contact local agriculture office or Krishi Vigyan Kendra
Submit application for specific component benefits

funding_pattern.description: Centrally Sponsored Scheme with varying cost-sharing by component

faq.q: What is the difference between NFSM and NFSNM?
faq.a: NFSNM is the 2024-25 rebranded version of NFSM that now includes a specific focus on nutri-cereals alongside the original target crops.

faq.q: What are the production targets under this mission?
faq.a: The mission aims to increase production of rice by 10 million tonnes, wheat by 8 million tonnes, pulses by 2 million tonnes, and boost production of coarse cereals.

faq.q: Who implements NFSNM?
faq.a: It is implemented by the Department of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare with support from ICAR, Krishi Vigyan Kendras, and State agriculture departments.

name: National Mission on Natural Farming (NMNF)
description: Approved by the Union Cabinet on November 25, 2024 as a standalone Centrally Sponsored Scheme to promote and scale up chemical-free natural farming practices across India.
target_group: Farmers interested in natural farming

other: Farmers willing to adopt chemical-free farming practices
Priority to clusters/villages for community adoption

benefits: Training on natural farming practices
Support for establishing 15,000 Gram-level clusters
Assistance for setting up 10,000 Bio-Input Resource Centers
Development of model demonstration farms
Simplified certification process
Market linkage support

steps: Attend mandatory training on natural farming practices
how_to_apply.deadline: Ongoing scheme with periodic enrollment windows

required_documents: Declaration of commitment to natural farming practices

faq.q: What is natural farming?
faq.a: Natural farming is a chemical-free farming approach that promotes the use of locally available resources, natural inputs, and biological processes for sustainable agriculture.

faq.q: When was NMNF approved?
faq.a: NMNF was approved in November 2024 as a standalone Centrally Sponsored Scheme.

faq.q: Who implements NMNF?
faq.a: It is implemented by the Department of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare in partnership with State Governments and PGS-India.

name: National Bamboo Mission
description: Restructured in 2018-19 under the National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture to promote bamboo cultivation on non-forest land, value-addition, market development, R&D, and marketing.
target_group: Farmers, entrepreneurs, and artisans in bamboo sector

other: Farmers with suitable land for bamboo cultivation
Entrepreneurs in bamboo processing and value addition
Artisans working with bamboo

benefits: Financial assistance for new bamboo plantations
Support for improved variety cultivation
Assistance for setting up processing units
Market development support
Skill development for bamboo craftspeople
Technology transfer and capacity building

faq.q: When was the National Bamboo Mission restructured?
faq.a: The National Bamboo Mission was restructured in 2018 under the National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture.

faq.q: What are the key focus areas of the National Bamboo Mission?
faq.a: The mission focuses on bamboo cultivation on non-forest land, value-addition, and marketing to increase farmers' income and strengthen the bamboo industry.

faq.q: Who are the nodal agencies for the National Bamboo Mission?
faq.a: The nodal agencies include the National Bamboo Mission at the central level and State Bamboo Development Boards at the state level.

name: Mission Organic Value Chain Development for North Eastern Region (MOVCD-NER)
description: Initiated in 2015-16 as a Central Sector Scheme to develop certified organic production and value chains in the eight North Eastern states of India.
target_group: Farmers in North Eastern states

eligibility.residency: Resident of North Eastern states (Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Sikkim, Tripura)
other: Farmers willing to adopt organic farming practices
Preference for those willing to join Farmer Producer Organizations

benefits: Assistance for organic certification
Support for forming Farmer Producer Organizations
Infrastructure development for collection, aggregation, and processing
Market access and brand development
End-to-end support across the value chain
Training on organic farming practices

steps: Join or form Farmer Producer Organizations if applicable

required_documents: Declaration of commitment to organic practices

funding_pattern.type: Central Sector Scheme with 100% funding from Central Government

faq.q: When was MOVCD-NER launched?
faq.a: MOVCD-NER was launched in 2015-16 as a Central Sector Scheme.

faq.q: What is the coverage target of MOVCD-NER?
faq.a: The scheme aims to cover over 50,000 hectares under organic farming in the North Eastern region.

faq.q: How many Farmer Producer Organizations are targeted under this scheme?
faq.a: The scheme aims to form approximately 100 Farmer Producer Organizations across the eight North Eastern states.

name: Kisan Credit Card (KCC) Scheme
description: Launched in August 1998 to provide farmers with timely access to short and medium-term credit for their cultivation, allied activities, and consumption needs.
target_group: All farmers, including small and marginal farmers

other: All farmers - individual/joint cultivators, tenant farmers, oral lessees, and sharecroppers
SHGs or Joint Liability Groups of farmers
Fishers, dairy farmers, and other allied agriculture practitioners

benefits: Short-term crop loans up to ₹3 lakh at 4% effective interest rate (with prompt repayment)
Interest subvention of 2% on timely repayment
Additional prompt repayment incentive of 3%
Coverage for term loans for agriculture and allied activities
Consumption loan component up to ₹10,000
ATM-enabled RuPay card facility

steps: Apply at nearest bank branch (commercial, regional rural, or cooperative)
Collect KCC and RuPay card after approval

implementing_agencies.description: Commercial banks, Regional Rural Banks, and Cooperative banks under RBI guidelines

faq.q: When was the KCC scheme introduced?
faq.a: The Kisan Credit Card scheme was introduced in 1998.

faq.q: What is the interest rate for KCC loans?
faq.a: The effective interest rate is 4% per annum for loans up to ₹3 lakh (with 2% interest subvention and 3% prompt repayment incentive).

faq.q: Can KCC be used for purposes other than crop production?
faq.a: Yes, KCC covers allied activities like animal husbandry, fisheries, and also includes a small consumption loan component.

name: Agri-Clinics & Agri-Business Centres (ACABC) Scheme
description: Launched in April 2002 to foster agri-entrepreneurship among agriculture graduates by providing training and credit-linked back-end subsidies for setting up agricultural service enterprises.
target_group: Agriculture graduates and rural entrepreneurs

other: Graduates in agriculture and allied subjects from recognized universities
Diploma holders in agriculture and allied fields
Biological science graduates with experience in agriculture
Intermediate in Agriculture (in some states)

benefits: Free two-month residential training on entrepreneurship development
Handholding support for one year after training
Credit-linked back-end subsidy (up to 36% of project cost)
Bank loans up to ₹20 lakh for individuals and ₹100 lakh for groups
Infrastructure support for establishment of agri-ventures

steps: Apply to nearest Nodal Training Institution
Prepare business plan with handholding support
Apply for bank loan and subsidy
how_to_apply.deadline: Ongoing scheme with regular training batches

implementing_agencies.description: Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare in coordination with MANAGE and State governments

faq.q: When was the ACABC scheme launched?
faq.a: The Agri-Clinics & Agri-Business Centres scheme was launched in 2002.

faq.q: What types of ventures can be established under ACABC?
faq.a: Ventures include soil testing labs, agri-input supply, farm machinery rentals, veterinary clinics, plant protection services, agriculture consulting, and many other agri-service businesses.

faq.q: Who provides the subsidy under ACABC?
faq.a: NABARD acts as the subsidy-channelizing agency for the scheme, while the funding comes from the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare.
